reviewText: Will we ever have world peace because sports players quit playing? No, quite likely instead it would tick off the soccer fans so bad they'd start their own war. Is this movie entertaining, even if unrealistic? Absolutely. Take a boy who wishes for world peace, a supporting family, and a sports legend that believes his dream and you have an enjoyable family movie. I am surprised Disney didn't come up with this one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Chuck Murdock is a good kid and a crack Little League pitcher from a small town in Montana. After taking a tour of nuclear missile siloes with his classmates, Chuck becomes obsessed by nuclear war and decides to stage a personal protest against it by refusing to play ball until the weapons are dismantled. A pro basketball player with the Boston Celtics named "Amazing" Grace Smith hears about Chuck's crusade and decides to join the kid's strike, moving out to Montana to be near him, annoying his agent (Jamie Lee Curtis), and convincing other pro athletes to come on board. All the notoriety turns the town against Chuck and his family, with his befuddled father (William Petersen) caught in the middle. Eventually, even the President (Gregory Peck) has to sit up and take notice. This Capra-like film, a classic what-one-person-can-achieve-if-he-puts-his-mind-to-it tale, is as sweet and clumsy as its title. Denver Nuggets star Alex English was a surprisingly photogenic and natural actor in his screen debut, and Red Auerbach cameo'd as himself. Director Mike Newell had mostly done TV before this 1987 effort, but would go on to make the much more accomplished "Enchanted April" and "Four Weddings and a Funeral."
summary: Capra-like; simple and clumsy but sweet

reviewText: Once again, here we are with the real world vs what some might LIKE it to be.  My boss told me in no uncertain terms once that dreams are nice but that is something you do at home in bed at night- get real guy and grow up!  I guess I have that wishful thinking that says anything is possible.  What I can not understand is why would a MEGA star like Gregory Peck appear in a production that is "the Worst Ever!".  I think we need to get off the merry-go-round of realism and start thinking outside the box - as one reviewer put it - The film is too didactic to be great, but its heart is in the right place.  And that is where it hit me - in the heart - not the head.  I was one of those kids that went ducking under my desk back in the 60's at my teachers direction to avoid a nuclear blast - YEAH - like that would work, what kind of fantasy is THAT? - so maybe I like to dream some and feel better about the world we live in, and this film takes me there.  Bottom line, if all you want is the "real deal", move on this film is not for you.
summary: OK - it could NEVER happen - but I am a glass half full person

reviewText: Yes, it is implausible.  Yes, some of the acting is stilted.  But good grief people - this is a make believe story.  And what an uplifting story it is.  You can sit down with your kids and watch this (I did - granted it was years ago when I had this on VHS).  I am pleased to see it out on DVD.  The transfer is pretty good.I won't bother giving you a synopsis of the story - others have done that already.  Suffice to say that it a good family movie with a moral - something sorely lacking in many movies that were put out since this one.And Gregory Peck!  What more could you ask for?  Get this movie NOW!

reviewText: It is fair to say that this movie changed my life.  After several viewings of this movie I was inspired to engage in a spiritual fast, not in a belief that my fasting would have a direct impact on the world stage, and it had an impact upon those around me.  For nearly three years I neither ate nor drank beverages from sun up to sun down.  Then, I saw a news clip on CNN of the Berlin Wall coming down and I went to my colleagues and told them we needed to go to lunch.  The world has changed and who we thought were the bad guys were guys who played from the same rule book as did we.  Now there are players on the world stage who scoff at our rule book on civilized violence.  Any person who believes that God wants us to kill other people for some silly difference of culture or tradition is so off the mark that, as a mental health professional, would qualify them for the label of insane.  Amazing Grace and Chuck taught me that even the least significant action can have a tremendous effect upon the world spirit, be it little league baseball or fasting everyday.  This movie is a great tool for educating people about world peace.  It can change lives.  BTW Greg Peck is awesome.
summary: Some people speak lightly of this movie and it's because they don't get it.

Then is was made available in digital format for half the price.  So I purchased it.  Not a VHS transfer and in widescreen.  Picture look clean and streams nice also have downloaded it to PC as backup so in case i want to watch it and internet is down.

reviewText: I know what went on in the film can't really happen in real life but isn't that what films are for?  Making you forget real life and enjoy the pretend that films bring.  This is such a film.  It is a sweet and lovely piece of what one boy can do for the world.  The actors who play the title characters are not the best actors I've seen but they convey the feelings perfectly.  William Petersen gives another stand out performance as Chuck's father along with Gregory Peck as the President and Jamie Lee Curtis in a small part.  This film is just fun and makes you wish that one person truly could affect the world as Chuck does.
